A method for evaluating the conditional probability of an event, particularly an unknown prior event, given that a known subsequent event has occurred.
A model for the analysis of time-series data which includes an autoregressive element based on a weighted average of past values, a moving average term, and the number of differencing passes.
A type of regression analysis in which the dependent variable is dichotomous.
The process by which a (usually numerical) value is assigned the level or state of some entity.
The Wilcoxon test is a non-parametric statistical test for significance across independent, correlated samples.

An analytic strategy associated with the French poststructuralist philosopher Jacques Derrida based on the assumption that language has no fixed meaning. A text, therefore, is interpreted through its relationship to various contexts.

In multiple regression multicollinearity is said to exist when two or more of the independent variables are themselves highly correlated, a situation that makes it difficult to establish the effect each has on the dependent variable.
A mixed effects model is a statistical model containing both fixed effects and random effects.
A measure of association describing a ratio of one odds to another.
Internal reliability can be thought of as the degree of consistency in the responses to a set or subset of items on a particular measure.
A term with a variety of meanings and historical resonances but which today usually refers to the intensive study of a small number of cases, or a single case.
The extent to which something that has been studied can be said to have been accurately depicted.
The extent to which a research account is believable, trustworthy and appropriate, with particular reference to the level of agreement between participants and the researcher.
A way of depicting frequency distributions for categorical variables.
Influences on the responses given during an interview that can be attributed to the characteristics of the interviewer.

A term with many meanings, poststructuralism is an intellectual movement that emerged in France in the 1960s. Poststructualism is characterised by a set of practices based around notions such as the decentering of the self, pantextualism (the notion that everything can be thought of as a text), intertextuality, and deconstructionism.
Secondary analysis is the analysis of data originally collected and analysed for another purpose
Inaccuracy that arises due to flaws in a measuring instrument or from the mistakes of those who use it.
The Kruskal-Wallist test is a non-parametric statistical test for analyzing variance between more than two independent samples.
The extent to which members of a cohort share experiences as a result of that membership. Researchers often wish to distinguish such effects from those due to ageing or historical period.
Stories told by individuals about their experiences.
A measure of the linear association between two ordinal variables.

A term that refers to a variety of methods for analysing text usually in a quantitative way that involves counting, coding comparing, contrasting, and categorizing the elements (most typically words) forming a corpus of textual data. Sometimes also used, probably inappropriately, to refer to the qualitative analysis of text.

A term associated with grounded theory, theoretical sampling refers to the process of selecting additional sample elements on the basis of their potential for confirming or disconfirming emerging theoretical formulations.
A test that provides an indication of how close the relationship is between data actually obtained and the theoretical distribution of the data based on the null hypothesis.
Interpretive repertoires can be thought of as sets of interconnected arguments, explanations, evaluations and descriptions frequently based on familiar anecdotes, illustrations, themes or clichŽs.

An approach focused on the identification and description of the methods and techniques that people use to produce and interpret social interaction, and which often involves detailed study of social practices such as greetings, giving directions or telling stories within a variety of formal or informal contexts.

A graphical display for showing information about a distribution in a convenient and intuitive way. Looking like a box with thin lines projecting above and below it, the plot allows one quickly to identify the distribution's minimum, maximum, median, and upper and lower quartiles.
Sampling bias occurs when some elements in a population are over- or underrepresented in a sample.
A philosophical doctrine which holds that there are no universal truths or absolute principles.
Highly detailed written accounts of how people in a social setting lead their lives, based on systematic and long-term observation of, and discussion with, those within the setting.
An approach to research that starts from the premise that knowledge derives from sense experience, and which usually relies heavily on observation or experiment.
A picture or likeness, generally made using a camera

A term with many meanings but broadly speaking the notion of reflexivity refers to the researcher's engaging in processes of self-awareness and self-criticism as an intrinsic feature of the research process.
The extent to which the findings of a study are relevant to subjects and settings beyond those in the study.
The use of the Internet to conduct primary or secondary research.
A form of non-probability sampling in which the researcher seeks out by various means sample members having characteristics relevant to the topic under study.
Using computer simulated models to study behaviour through adjusting particular variables and observing how these changes affect the outcomes.

A term with no precise equivalent in English, it refers to a form of human action concerned with what is right and good in a given situation, and the competence, sensibility, and sensitivity required to make such judgements.
A discipline's general orientation or way of seeing its subject matter.
Predicting future events or trends on the basis of past information about them.
In statistics, moderation is where the relationship between the independent variable and the dependent variable is contingent upon a third variable.
Multiple methods research involves more than one method being used in study.
A statistical measure named after the statistician Karl Pearson, the coefficient measures the strength of the relationship between two interval or ratio variables. It varies between +1 and -1.

A growing movement in qualitative research, particularly in applied fields such as education and health, which seeks to draw on and integrate into research practice work traditionally associated with the arts including but not restricted to poetry, drama, dance, music, and visual expression.
A square matrix formed of the covariances of variables.
In game theory, the Nash equilibrium is defined as a conceptual solution to analyze strategic interactions and the strategic options for each game player.

A constant, systematic form or source of error in research arising either from the researcher's conscious or unconscious predelictions or from features of the context within which the research is produced that tend to predetermine research findings.
An estimate of how a sample statistic is expected to differ from a population parameter in a random sample drawn from the population.
Someone recognised as capable of providing authoritative knowledge and judgement within some particular domain.
The statistical association between two variables measured at ordinal, interval or ratio level. Many different 'correlation co-efficients' are used as measures of association.
The degree of scatter or variability in a set of observations.
Any of a number of qualitative research approaches influenced by phenomenological philosophy that aim to understand how people make sense of their everyday life.
Ecological validity refers to the extent to which something studied in one environment such as a laboratory setting can be generalised to a range of other, typically 'real world', environments.
A field of post-structuralism that studies sexuality, gender identity and LGBT history.

Although there is some disagreement about the term, feminist research is an approach to social research in which topics are chosen and methods used in ways that challenge methodologies developed by men, and with the aim of enhancing the position of women in society.
The processes involved in capturing unstructured data through (usually lengthy) processes of interviewing or observation.
Study skills refers to the skills that an individual requires to be successful in their studies.

Research aimed at identifying similarities and differences between social entities. While the term is sometimes widened to include comparisons between many different types of entity, it often refers to research comparing nation states, societies, or cultures.
The extent to which for a given coding scheme two or more coders independently agree on the coding of some content.
The principles and procedures characteristic of science and, more particularly, the natural sciences.
An introspective method that values first person perspectives and alternative ways of knowing.

Although the term is used somewhat differently in different disciplines, it generally refers to research involving data collected at more than one point in time and focused on the measurement and analysis of change over time in the units of study.

(Also referred to as CATI.) A mode of data collection on surveys in which a computer system is used to select and contact respondents who are then interviewed over the telephone with their responses being entered into the computer.
Public opinion research involves the conceptualization and measurement of what people think or how they behave.

The basis proposition encapsulating an intellectual position Also, a document, often also referred to as a dissertation, presenting research findings offered in support of candidature for a higher academic qualification.
Data generated by respondents thinking back to past occasions or states.

Measures of association refer to a wide variety of coefficients that measure the statistical strength of the relationship on the variables of interest. These measures of association, are described in several ways, depending on the analysis.
A branch of mathematics particularly relevant to the social sciences to the study of social networks.
A form of group interview centred on a particular topic or activity and in which the interaction within the group is used to facilitate the elicitation of participants' views.

The exploration of physical and spatial features of a particular environment which are associated with certain social outcomes, such as social exclusion or crime, and are therefore seen as having a contributory or perhaps causal effect on social processes or social phenomena.
The total set of something that is or has been studied. The term can refer to any set of entities not just all the people who live in a particular country.
The study of a cohort (a set of individuals who have experienced a particular event at the same time) over an extended period.

A term associated with the American sociologist Erving Goffman, impression management refers to the way in which individuals attempt to maintain through interactional strategies of various kinds a positive image of themselves in the eyes of others.
Usually, the difference between observed and expected values based on an estimated model of some kind.

An approach to discourse analysis, politically committed to social change in favour of oppressed social groups, that aims to explicate the role of discursive practice in producing and maintaining unequal power relations.
Doing research refers to the act of carrying out research through data collection and data analysis.
A variable that varies in ways the researcher does not control. For example, age is a random variable if we simply select people regardless of what age they are.
A concept associated with the sociologist Erving Goffman, the interaction order refers to the totality of constraint and possibility implicit in and emerging out of co-present interaction.
The use of qualitative approaches to examine those activities that are mediated by information and communication technologies such as the Internet.

In factor analysis, a statistic indicating how much of the variation in the original group of variables is accounted for by a particular factor. It has similar uses in other forms of multivariate analysis.

Although the term can have several slightly different meanings, it generally refers to a research method that involves asking a sample of people a set of pre-prepared questions on a single occasion in order to gather data about their opinions and behaviour.

The process of rendering into textual form material that was originally produced in another medium, for example by typing up the content of a recorded interview. Often the analyst makes a conscious decision on theoretical grounds about the amount of detail to be included.

A rather contested term with a number of different meanings. It refers very broadly to view that it is possible and desirable to apply to the study of social life the methods, concepts and procedures of the natural sciences.
In statistics, the range is the difference between the highest and lowest values of a variable.

Those scholars and their students in the Department of Sociology at the University of Chicago in the period between the two world wars whose work is seen (sometimes in mythologised ways) as foundational for the development of qualitative methods. A postwar group at Chicago influenced by this tradition is sometimes referred to as the 'second Chicago school'.
Sometimes used to refer to epistemological positions that are explicitly non-positivist, but the term is also used to describe contemporary less strict and more 'moderate' forms of positivism.
The extent to which you can come to conclusions about one thing (often a population) based on information about another (often a sample).

A method of statistical inference named after Thomas Bayes, an 18th-century English mathematician. The method involves working backwards from effect to cause, by estimating the conditional probability of a cause given that certain events have occurred. Bayesian inference involves using new information, called the posterior probability, to revise earlier estimates of probability, called prior probability.
A methodological approach in which, usually over a lengthy period, a researcher becomes involved, either overtly or covertly, in a setting, culture, group or organisation in order to study it.

Data from a study in which a group of people is followed over time from a common starting point. At each time period data are collected relevant to that specific period thus obviating the problems that arise from retrospective reporting of past events.
When examining the relationship between two variables, the assertion that the independent variable has no effect on the dependent variable or that there is no association between the two variables.

Broadly speaking, the study of research methods extending from broad issues relating to epistemology, through the theoretical principles underpinning particular methods, to specific procedures for conducting research. Sometimes (incorrectly) used interchangeably with terms such as research methods or research design.

In qualitative research, a procedure by which raw data, often but not always in the form of elicited speech which has been recorded in some way, are transformed into meaningful and theoretically meaningful categories. In quantitative research, the process of categorising data from open-ended questions.

A term associated with the anthropologist Clifford Geertz, thick description does not only imply that ethnographic description should be highly detailed but that it should attend to the circumstances, meanings, intentions, strategies, motivations, and so on that characterise a particular episode.
A computer program for analysing structural equation models. LISREL stands for 'Linear Structural Relations'.

The principle that information gathered from or about research participants in the course of a study is private and should only be revealed to third parties with the explicit consent of the individuals from whom the information was obtained.
A continuous variable is one within whose range of values any value is possible.

It is common in the social sciences to study populations which are themselves embedded within other populations, for example pupils, classrooms, schools. Multilevel analysis is a statistical approach which allows the simultaneous modelling of processes across such different units of analysis.

A field research method used primarily in pre-testing survey instruments which allows researchers to collect verbal information regarding survey responses and is used to evaluate whether the question is measuring what the researcher intends.
The major paradigms or ways of making knowledge claims about the social world, such as positivism and interpretivism.
A set of instructions carried out in a specified order to accomplish the completion of a specific task.
In statistical hypothesis testing the error that results from rejecting a null hypothesis that is true.

In general the processes involved in rendering meaning from one language into another while attempting to retain the sense of the original. In survey research the attempt to retain the standardised meaning of survey questions when a questionnaire is translated. In Actor Network Theory translation refers to a process by which networks come to be developed.
The analysis of changes in variables over time. Also used to refer to the statistical procedures associated with such analysis.
Data sharing refers to the process of making data available for other researchers to use.
A variable that distinguishes among subjects by sorting them into a limited number of categories, indicating type or kind.
A number indicating the values of a dependent variable associated with the values of an independent variable or variables.
Using a set of digital tools and techniques to extract and analyse data from social media channels and the online sphere.
Aspects of subjects’ “backgrounds” that may influence other variables, but will not be influenced by them. Often demographic characteristics.
Data deriving directly from observation, experimention, or elicitation.
A procedure in the grounded theory approach to qualitative data analysis in which each finding and interpretation that emerges from the data is compared with existing codes and categories.
Developed by the American psychologist Clyde Coombs, a method for measuring preferences towards something that does not require assumptions about the underlying consistency of the preferences.
A philosophical doctrine based on the view that reasoning is the main way in which humans attain knowledge.
Data collection skills refers to the skills that an individual requires to effectively collect and curate data for research purposes.
In meta-analysis, a simple tally of the extent to which the various research reports being considered support or fail to support the hypothesis being studied.
Safe fieldwork is fieldwork in which the researcher is aware of possible threats to their safety and takes steps to minimize risk.
A circle with areas (“slices”) marked to represent the proportion of total units in each category.
A term coined by the American sociologist, Harold Garfinkel, ethnomethodology investigates the constitutive organisation of social interaction.
The branch of statistics which deals with generalization from samples to population parameters.
The process of repeatedly taking samples from a sample to estimate what other samples from a population would look like were they available.
Computer-assisted methods of information retrieval by extracting and organising knowledge from unstructured text.

The process of breaking apart. In the social sciences often refers to the proliferation of sub-disciplines and specialisms within a particular area. In qualitative research can refer to the extent to an analysis decontextualises the data.
An approach propounded by Karl Marx which sees the development of human society as grounded in the ways in which human beings produce the material conditions of life.
Statistical data analysis directed toward data measured at the nominal or ordinal level.
A term sometimes used to refer to nominal-level or categorical data.
In regression analysis the rule that the line of best fit is found where the sum of the squared residuals is minimised.
A relationship between two or more variables that cannot be represented by a line in a two-dimensional space or a plane in a three-dimensional space.
An approach that proceeds from the assumption that individuals balance costs and benefits in making decisions.
A measure of association used when each variable is measured at the ordinal level and where both variables are taken from a continuous bivariate distribution.
Latent variables are variable that are not directly observed in data. Instead they are inferred from observed variables through the application of a mathematical model of some kind.
A rather general term that refers to research based solely or primarily on documentary sources as opposed to data produced by other means.
Methods aimed at capturing experiences that take place 'on the move'. Also, methods utilising new information and communication technologies such as mobile phones to capture data.

The term refers to a range of multivariate statistical procedures used to determine whether some set of entities of interest to the researcher, such as individuals, responses, or cases, are similar enough to be grouped together into clusters. While the entities within the cluster are similar to one another, the clusters themselves are dissimilar.
The paired t-test is a statistical test for comparing correlated samples, pretest and posttest.
A research strategy involving comparison across two or more nation states.
A graphic representation of inequality or dispersion in a frequency distribution.
Insider action research is when action research is carried out by a researcher within their own organization or community.
Graphical methods of depicting the degree of association in cross tabulations.
The social study of language as used in talk, text and other forms of communication.
Data sets so large or complex that traditional data processing tools are inadequate.
The mean (average) of a set of scores in matrix algebra.
A method for checking the reliability of an measure by seeing how far the scores on half of the items correlate with the scores on the other half.
The study of health problems in a population, especially infectious disease.
A range of values so defined that one can specify the probability that the value of a population parameter lies within it.
A range of methods, procedures and approaches for producing and interpreting stories or narratives of people's lives.
When an eligible sample member fails to respond to all, or some, items.
Nonprobability sampling refers to procedures in which researchers select their sample elements not based on a predetermined probability.
A statistical procedure designed to assess whether differences in the means of two groups reflect differences in their respective populations or are simply due to chance.
